339 Here LSB returns to the idea of virtue from an evolutionary standpoint. Unlike her earlier articles, however, this one does not argue that humanity favours the virtuous as the best method for its own propagation, but rather argues for doing away with the idea of virtue altogether. LSB maintains here that the only measure of success is survival, and that virtue is contextual. Fitness is not usefulness, it is adaptedness. Where there is mud, gills beat lungs; where there is air, lungs beat gills; where there is despair, brutality mocks culture; where there is comfort, there is no discontent, noble or ignoble.

DIV0.BIOGPROSE: (Louisa Sarah, later Mrs Ignatz Guggenberger), 1845-?95, journalist and poet, b. Battersea, London, to Louisa (De Hermes?) and Alexander B., 'gentleman', probably of Quaker family. The eldest of eight (seven girls), LSB pub. her first book of poems as 'Arbor Leigh' in 1876, followed by {FCabbrevTitle}Key-Notes{/FCabbrevTitle}, 1879 (as L. S. Bevington), which shows signs of querying established Christian codes. Her article on 'Atheism and Morality' ({FCabbrevTitle}Nineteenth Century{/FCabbrevTitle}, Oct. 1879) provoked a clerical essay in reply. After {FCabbrevTitle}Poems, Lyrics and Sonnets{/FCabbrevTitle}, 1882, containing some interesting metrical experiments and laments for dead Christianity, in 1883 she m. Munich artist Ignatz G. By 1895 she was publishing with James Tochetti's 'Liberty' Press (a journal of 'Anarchist Communism') poems which, in Browningesque fable guise, offer a {Running Head} 92 BIDDLE, HESTER> sharp critique of moral half-measures (e.g. 'The Spider and the Bee, A Tale for the Times').
